newsitem.title: UK: Britain's wealthiest Asian plans $2.8 bln listing.
newsitem.headline: Britain's wealthiest Asian plans $2.8 bln listing.

text.p: Lakshmi Mittal, one of Britain's wealthiest businessman who made a fortune out of turning around loss-making steel companies worldwide, is planning a $2.8 billion stock market flotation.

Sources close to the issue said on Wednesday that Indian-born Mittal, 47, plans to raise about $450 million by selling some 16 percent control in his family-owned Ispat International group which will be listed on the New York and Amsterdam Stock Exchanges.
Set up in 1989 and based in the Netherlands, Ispat International now owns steel mills in Canada, Ireland, Germany, Mexico and the islands of the Caribbean.

The sources told Reuters that about 19.25 million shares are expected to be listed in the $22-$26 range. The issue is being handled by Credit Suisse First Boston and Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette. The prospectus for the issue is due to be published next week.
The company had reported net profits of about $615 million on a turnover of $1.8 billion in 1996 on an annual output of nearly six million tonnes of steel.
Mittal, born to a family which started business out of a small scrap metal yard in Calcutta in India, went it alone when he moved to Indonesia in his mid-20s.

Specialising in both flat and long products made in electric mini-arc mills instead of the usual blast furnaces, Ispat's first major breakthrough was the acquisition of what is now Caribbean Ispat in Trinidad & Tobago.
Its second big coup was the $220 million purchase of one of Mexico's largest steel mills based in Lazaro Cardenas along the Pacific coast in 1992.
Benefiting from a weak peso combined with strong exports, the operation, now called Ispat Mexicana, had pre-tax earnings of $211 million in 1995 and is now undergoing an expansion drive.
Since then Ispat has taken over Sidbec-Dosco in Canada, the formerly state-owned Irish Steel and Hamberger Stahlwerker in Germany. The group is also buying two mills from Thyssen Stahl in Germany.
Ispat will be using the bulk of the funds on capital expenditure after paying off a loan of $90 million.
Mittal's larger holding group is LNM Group and it recorded a turnover of more than $2.7 billion including operations in Indonesia and Kazakhstan which will not be part of the flotation.
He faces the daunting task of turning around Karmet Steel in Kazakhstan, which is struggling to find its way after the demise of the Soviet Union.
Karmet, however, was bought due to its proximity to one of the world's largest coking coal deposits, important to reduce costs of making steel.
Mittal and his wife Usha currently hold full control of Ispat. He moved his base to London in 1995 and now lives in a plush mansion in north London.
